levels.asideSubTitle: Select elements by their type
levels.asideText: Selects all elements of type A. Type refers to the type of tag, so <div>, <p> and <ul> are all different element types.
levels.asideExamples:
div selects all <div> elements.
p selects all <p> elements.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </plate>
 </plate>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select elements by their type
levels.asideText: Selects all elements of type A. Type refers to the type of tag, so <div>, <p> and <ul> are all different element types.
levels.asideExamples:
div selects all <div> elements.
p selects all <p> elements.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </bento>
 </plate>
 </bento>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select elements with an ID
levels.asideText: Selects the element with a specific id. You can also combine the ID selector with the type selector.
levels.asideExamples:
#cool selects any element with id="cool".
ul#long selects ul id="long"
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </plate id = "fancy" >
 </plate>
 </bento>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select an element inside another element
levels.asideText: Selects all B inside of A. B is called a descendant because it is inside of another element.
levels.asideExamples:
p strong selects all <strong> elements that are inside of any <p>
#fancy span selects any <span> elements that are inside of the element with id="fancy"
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </bento>
 <plate>
  </apple>
 </plate>
 </apple>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Combine the Descendant & ID Selectors
levels.asideText: You can combine any selector with the descendent selector.
levels.asideExamples:
#cool span selects all <span> elements that are inside of elements with id="cool"
#fancy span selects any <span> elements that are inside of the element with id="fancy"
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <bento>
  </orange>
 </bento>
 <plate id ="fancy">
  </blueberry>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  </blueberry>
 </plate>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select elements by their class
levels.asideText: The class selector selects all elements with that class attribute. Elements can only have one ID, but many classes.
levels.asideExamples: .neato selects all elements with class="neato"
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </apple>
 </apple class = "small">
 <plate>
  </apple class = "small">
 </plate>
 </plate>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Combine the Class Selector
levels.asideText: You can combine the class selector with other selectors, like the type selector.
levels.asideExamples:
ul.important selects all <span> elements that have class="important"
#big.wide selects all elements with id="big" that also have class="wide"
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </apple>
 </apple class = "small">
 <bento>
  </orange class = "small">
 </bento>
 <plate>
  </orange>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  </orange class = "small">
 </plate>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: You can do it...
levels.asideText: Combine what you learned in the last few levels to solve this one!
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <bento>
  </orange>
 </bento>
 </orange class="small">
 <bento>
  </orange class="small">
 </bento>
 <bento>
  </apple class="small">
 </bento>
 <bento>
  </orange class="small">
 </bento>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Combine, selectors, with... commas!
levels.asideText: Thanks to Shatner technology, this selects all A and B elements. You can combine any selectors this way, and you can specify more than two.
levels.asideExamples:
ul.important selects all <p> elements as well as all elements with class="fun"
a, p, div selects all <p>, <a>, <div> elements
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </blueberry class="small">
 </blueberry>
 <plate>
  </blueberry class="small">
 </plate>
 <bento>
  </blueberry>
 </bento>
 <plate>
  </blueberry class="small">
 </plate>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: You can select everything!
levels.asideText: You can select all elements with the universal selector!
levels.asideExamples: p * selects any element inside all <p> elements.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </apple>
 <plate>
  </orange class="small">
 </plate>
 <bento>
 <bento>
  </orange>
 </bento>
 </plate id = "fancy">
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Combine the Universal Selector
levels.asideText: This selects all elements inside of A.
levels.asideExamples:
p * selects any element inside all <p> elements.
ul.fancy * selects every element inside all <ul class="fancy"> elements
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <plate id="fancy">
  </orange class="small">
 </plate>
 <plate>
  </blueberry class ="small">
 </plate>
 </apple class="small">
 <plate>
  </apple>
 </plate>
</div>

levels.select: every apple that's next to a plate
levels.asideSubTitle: Select an element that directly follows another element
levels.asideText:
This selects all B elements that directly follow A. Elements that follow one another are called siblings. They're on the same level, or depth.

In the HTML markup for this level, elements that have the same indentation are siblings.
levels.asideExamples:
p + .intro selects every element with class="intro" that directly follows a <p>.
div + a selects every <a> element that directly follows a <div>
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <bento>
  </apple class="small">
 </bento>
 </plate>
 </apple class="small">
 </plate>
 </apple>
 </apple class="small">
 </apple class="small">
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select elements that follows another element
levels.asideText: You can select all siblings of an element that follow it. This is like the Adjacent Selector (A + B) except it gets all of the following elements instead of one.
levels.asideExamples: A ~ B selects all B that follow a A.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </blueberry>
 <bento>
  </orange class="small">
 </bento>
  </blueberry class="small">
 </blueberry>
 <plate>
  <blueberry>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <blueberry class="small">
 </plate>
</div>

levels.select: the apple directly on a plate
levels.asideSubTitle: Select direct children of an element
levels.asideText:
You can select elements that are direct children of other elements. A child element is any element that is nested directly in another element.
Elements that are nested deeper than that are called descendant elements.
levels.asideExamples: A > B selects all B that are a direct children A.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <plate>
  <bento>
   </apple>
  </bento>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <apple>
 </plate>
 </plate>
 </apple>
 </apple class ="small">
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select a first child element inside of another element
levels.asideText: You can select the first child element. A child element is any element that is directly nested in another element. You can combine this pseudo-selector with other selectors.
levels.asideExamples: :first-child selects all first child elements.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </bento>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  </orange>
  </orange>
  </orange>
 </plate>
 </blueberry class="small">
</div>

levels.select: the apple and the blueberry on the plates
levels.asideSubTitle: Select an element that are the only element inside of another one.
levels.asideText: You can select any element that is the only element inside of another one.
levels.asideExamples:
span:only-child selects the <span> elements that are the only child of some other element..
ul li:only-child selects the only <li> element that are in a <ul>
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <plate>
  <apple>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <blueberry>
 </plate>
 <bento>
  <blueberry>
 </bento>
 <plate>
  <orange class="small">
  <orange>
 </plate>
 </blueberry class="small">
</div>

levels.select: the small apple and the blueberry
levels.asideSubTitle: Select the last element inside of another element
levels.asideText:
You can use this selector to select an element that is the last child element inside of another element.

Pro Tip → In cases where there is only one element, that element counts as the first-child, only-child and last-child!
levels.asideExamples:
:last-child selects all last-child elements.
span:last-child selects all last-child <span> elements.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <plate id="fancy">
  <apple class="small">
 </plate>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <orange class="small">
  <orange>
 </plate>
 </blueberry>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select an element by its order in another element
levels.asideText: Selects the nth (Ex: 1st, 3rd, 12th etc.) child element in another element.!
levels.asideExamples:
:nth-child(8) selects every element that is the 8th child of another element.
div p:nth-child(2) selects the second p in every div.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </plate>
 </plate>
 </plate>
 </plate id="fancy">
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select an element by its order in another element, counting from the back
levels.asideText: Selects the children from the bottom of the parent. This is like nth-child, but counting from the back
levels.asideExamples: :nth-last-child(2) selects all second-to-last child elements.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </plate>
 </bento>
 <plate>
  </orange>
  </orange>
  </orange>
 </plate>
 </bento>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select the first element of a specific type
levels.asideText: Selects the first element of that type within another element.
levels.asideExamples: span:first-of-type selects the first <span> in any element.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </orange class="small">
 </apple>
 </apple class="small">
 </apple>
 </apple class="small">
 <plate>
  </orange class="small">
  </orange>
 </plate>
</div>

levels.asideText: Selects a specific element based on its type and order in another element - or even or odd instances of that element.
levels.asideExamples:
div:nth-of-type(2) selects the second instance of a div.
.example:nth-of-type(odd) selects all odd instances of a the example class.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </plate>
 </plate>
 </plate>
 </plate>
 </plate id="fancy">
 </plate>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Nth-of-type Selector with Formula
levels.asideText: The nth-of-type formula selects every nth element, starting the count at a specific instance of that element.
levels.asideExamples: span:nth-of-type(6n+2) selects every 6th instance of a <span> , starting from (and including) the second instance.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <blueberry>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <apple class="small">
 </plate>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <apple>
 </plate>
 </plate>
</div>

levels.select: the apple on the middle plate
levels.asideSubTitle: Select elements that are the only ones of their type within of their parent element
levels.asideText: Selects the only element of its type within another element.
levels.asideExamples: p span:only-of-type selects a <span> within any <p> if it is the only <span> in there.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <plate>
  </apple class="small">
  </apple>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <apple class="small">
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <blueberry>
 </plate>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select the last element of a specific type
levels.asideText: Selects each last element of that type within another element. Remember type refers the kind of tag, so <p> and <span> are different types.
levels.asideExamples: div:last-of-type selects the last <div> in every element.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </orange class="small">
 </orange class="small">
 </blueberry>
 </blueberry>
 </apple class="small">
 </apple class="small">
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select elements that don't have children
levels.asideText: Selects elements that don't have any other elements inside of them.
levels.asideExamples: div:empty selects all empty <div> elements.
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 </bento>
 <bento>
  <blueberry>
 </bento>
 </plate>
 </bento>
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select all elements that don't match the negation selector
levels.asideText: You can use this to select all elements that do not match selector "X".
levels.asideExamples:
:not(#fancy) selects all elements that do not have id="fancy".
div:not(:first-child) selects every <div> that is not a first child.
:not(.big, .medium) selects all elements that do not have class="big" or class="medium"
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <plate id="fancy">
  <apple>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <apple>
 </plate>
 </apple>
 <plate>
  <orange class="small">
 </plate>
 </blueberry class="small">
</div>

levels.asideSubTitle: Select all elements that don't match the negation selector
levels.asideText: You can use this to select all elements that do not match selector "X".
levels.asideExamples:
:not(#fancy) selects all elements that do not have id="fancy".
div:not(:first-child) selects every <div> that is not a first child.
:not(.big, .medium) selects all elements that do not have class="big" or class="medium"
levels.HTMLeditor:
<div class="table">
 <plate id="fancy">
  <apple>
 </plate>
 <plate>
  <apple>
 </plate>
 </apple>
 <plate>
  <orange class="small">
 </plate>
 </blueberry class="small">
</div>
